name: Physics II for Engineering and Physics Students

prereqs.text: ((33-106 [] at least D) and (21-120 [] at least D)) or ((33-141 [] at least D) and (21-120 [] at least D)) or ((21-120 [] at least D) and (33-111 [] at least D)) or ((21-120 [] at least D) and (33-131 [] at least D)) or ((21-120 [] at least D) and (33-151 [] at least D)) or ((21-120 [] at least D) and (33-121 [] at least D))

long_desc: This is the second half of a twosemester calculusbased introductory physics sequence for engineering and physics students. Two fifths of the course covers electricity, including electrostatics and electric fields, Gauss law, electric potential, and simple circuits. Two fifths cover magnetism, including magnetic forces, magnetic fields, induction and electromagnetic radiation. One fifth of the course covers mechanical waves including standing and traveling waves, superposition, and beats and electromagnetic waves including mode of propagation, speed, and other properties. This course has a corequisite of 21122.

custom_fields.goals: To introduce you to the wonderful concepts of electromagnetism and to help you to learn how to model relevant physical systems and to be able to perform rigorous calculations and solve problems related to them.
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: A mechanics course (33-141 or 33-121 or 33-151), a calculus course (21-120), and 21-122 is a co-requisite
custom_fields.assessment_structure: Problem sets 35%, three subject examinations 30%, final examination 30%, recitation attendance 5%
custom_fields.relevance: This course is primarily designed for both engineers who would like to learn some physics as well as physics students.
custom_fields.learning_resources: The course will have multiple help sessions and office hours every week.
